title: Understanding Hysteroscopy
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: A hysteroscopy is a **simple procedure** that allows a doctor to look inside your uterus (womb) using a thin telescope-like camera called a hysteroscope.

items.title: Two Types
items.description: Diagnostic Hysteroscopy — To diagnose problems. Operative Hysteroscopy — To treat problems.

items.title: Quick Facts
items.description: Diagnostic hysteroscopy is usually a short procedure, while operative hysteroscopy may take longer depending on the treatment. It is considered a safe and effective procedure, and most hysteroscopies are performed as outpatient procedures.

content.title: Remember
content.description: Hysteroscopy is commonly offered for abnormal bleeding or fertility issues. It is a safe and effective way to diagnose and treat many common womb problems.

content.value: If you experience any of the following symptoms, you should seek medical advice and possibly consider a hysteroscopy:

items: Difficulty getting pregnant or repeated miscarriages

content.value: Before scheduling a hysteroscopy, you will have a consultation with your doctor to discuss:

items: Your medical history and current symptoms
Potential need for the procedure based on your symptoms
Explanation of the procedure and any risks involved
Any alternative tests or treatments that may be appropriate

content.title: Additional Tips
content.description: It's important to be fully prepared for your hysteroscopy to ensure a smooth process. You may need to: Arrange for transportation home if sedation is required. Discuss any concerns with your healthcare provider beforehand.

content.value: Simple steps to prepare for your procedure

steps: Pregnancy test: You may need a pregnancy test before the procedure to ensure it is safe to proceed.
Use contraception: Avoid becoming pregnant before your hysteroscopy, as the procedure cannot be done during pregnancy.
Pre-treatment medicine: In some cases, medication may be given beforehand (for example before fibroid treatment) depending on your individual care plan.

content.title: What to Expect
content.description: Your healthcare team will give you specific instructions based on your individual case. Don't hesitate to ask questions about preparation or the procedure itself.

items.title: Timing
items.description: Most hysteroscopies are done as an outpatient or day-case procedure, meaning you can usually go home the same day. A diagnostic hysteroscopy is typically quick, while an operative hysteroscopy may take longer depending on what treatment is being carried out.

items.title: Anaesthetic Options
items.description: Many hysteroscopy procedures are done without general anaesthetic. Local anaesthetic may be used to reduce discomfort, while general anaesthetic might be recommended for certain procedures depending on your individual situation.

steps: Positioning — You lie on a couch with your legs supported
Speculum Use — A speculum may be used to gently hold the vagina open
Hysteroscope Insertion — The hysteroscope is passed into the womb through the vagina and cervix
Fluid Expansion — Fluid is gently pumped in to expand the womb and improve visibility

Examination & Treatment — A camera sends images to a monitor so your doctor can examine the inside of the womb. If treatment is planned, small instruments can be used through the hysteroscope to treat abnormalities.

content.title: What You'll Feel
content.description: You may feel cramping similar to period pain. Some people experience discomfort or pain, but this is usually short-lived. The procedure is generally well tolerated, and your team can provide pain relief if needed.

items.title: What's Normal
items.description: After a hysteroscopy, it’s normal to have mild cramps (similar to period pain) and some spotting or light bleeding for a few days. Most people feel well enough to return to their normal activities within a day or two.

items.title: Self-Care Tips
items.description: After your hysteroscopy, you can eat and drink as normal. If you’ve had a general anaesthetic or sedation, it’s best to rest and take things easy for the remainder of the day. Avoid vaginal sex until any bleeding or discharge has stopped, and use pain relief such as paracetamol or ibuprofen if needed (as long as it’s safe for you).

content.title: Results Discussion
content.description: Your doctor will discuss your results and next steps before you leave. Make sure to ask any questions you have about your findings or follow-up care.

content.title: Recovery Timeline
content.description: Day 1: Many people return to normal activities, depending on the procedure. First 24 hours (if you had general anaesthetic or sedation): Rest, and avoid driving, alcohol, or important decisions. After the procedure: Avoid vaginal sex until any bleeding or discharge has stopped

content.value: Important warning signs to watch for

content.text: Contact Your Doctor Urgently If You Have:

items.title: Heavy Bleeding
items.description: Soaking a pad every hour or passing large clots

content.title: Emergency Contact
content.description: These symptoms may be signs of infection or complications (which are rare). Don't hesitate to contact your healthcare provider if you're concerned about any symptoms.

items.title: Normal:
items.description: After a hysteroscopy, it’s normal to have mild cramping, light spotting for a few days, and a slight discharge as your body recovers.

items.title: Concerning:
items.description: After a hysteroscopy, you should seek medical advice if you experience heavy or worsening bleeding, a high fever, severe or increasing pain, or foul-smelling discharge, as these can be signs of infection or complications.
